{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3547917,"name":"Landon","username":"Lfehr","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/47e85d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-05T03:27:17.408Z","cooked":"

Hello,
My team is using YAGSL swerve code for our mk4 L2 swerve drive and when driving straight the bot tends to start turning. And sometimes the bot is not able to go from straight to left or right without having to move the bot forward or backward any suggestions?
Github: GitHub - 7657thunderbots/FRC2025-REEFSCAPE

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-05T03:27:17.408Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":72,"readers_count":71,"score":39.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":494308,"topic_slug":"yagsl-neo-mk4-l2-swerve-drift","display_username":"Landon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/7657thunderbots/FRC2025-REEFSCAPE","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - 7657thunderbots/FRC2025-REEFSCAPE","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53962,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/yagsl-neo-mk4-l2-swerve-drift/494308/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3548087,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-05T10:51:50.035Z","cooked":"

Your “D” term on the angle PID is higher than ours (and higher than I’d expect). If you’ve tuned it carefully, that could be right, but if you’re stabbing numbers in hoping it gets better, start with 0 “I” and 0 “D” and tune P first. If it drives acceptably from there, I would be inclined to minimize the “D” (and “I”) terms.

Also, based on my understanding the “F” term should always be zero for angle [and lateral drive] motor control.

Also: Are your swerve modules turning freely?

We had some first-year students get overly ambitious (and insufficiently mechanically sympathetic) in prepping for the first match and their efforts resulted in two modules that weren’t like the others in terms of freedom of swivel of the angle gears.

I’d approach it as:

  1. Verify mechanical condition. (Jack the bot up, turn the modules by hand. If they all feel about the same [slightly clicky is OK], move on.)
  2. Set the F term to 0. Redeploy and retest.
  3. Set the D term to 0. Redeploy and retest.

im not sure how you do this in yagsl since my team uses custom swerve code, but make sure your zeroed positions of your absolute encoders are good as well as ensuring your PID tuning is good.
